Epstein Zorro Ranch: The Desert Compound

In the high desert of New Mexico, about an hour southeast of Santa Fe, lies a 10,000-acre property that Jeffrey Epstein called Zorro Ranch. Named after the fictional vigilante, this remote compound was where Epstein could escape civilization - and, allegedly, its laws. What happened at Zorro Ranch remains one of the darker chapters of the Epstein story.

A Ranch Like No Other

Zorro Ranch wasn't a typical ranch. Epstein purchased the property in the 1990s and poured millions into its development:
  • The Main House: A sprawling mansion of over 33,000 square feet
  • Private Airstrip: Allowing direct arrival by private plane
  • Guest Accommodations: Multiple buildings for visitors
  • Infrastructure: Water systems, power generation, and staff facilities
The scale of the property was staggering - larger than some small towns. Epstein could host dozens of guests, conduct business, and maintain total privacy from the outside world.

Scientific Patronage and Strange Ambitions

Epstein used Zorro Ranch to cultivate his image as a patron of science:
  • Santa Fe Institute: He hosted events and donated to the research center
  • Visiting Scientists: Researchers from around the world visited the ranch
  • Transhumanism: Epstein was fascinated by life extension and genetic engineering
But his scientific interests took a dark turn. Multiple sources reported that Epstein wanted to use the ranch for a breeding program - to impregnate women and 'seed' his DNA into future generations. The plan was never realized, but it revealed the extent of Epstein's megalomania.

Political Connections in New Mexico

Epstein cultivated relationships with New Mexico's political elite:
  • Bill Richardson: The former governor visited Epstein and received campaign contributions
  • Local Officials: County commissioners and local politicians were part of his circle
  • Michele Roberts: A prominent attorney who represented Epstein victims
These connections helped Epstein maintain a low profile in New Mexico. When questions arose about his activities, he had friends in positions of influence.

Abuse Allegations at the Ranch

Survivors have alleged that abuse occurred at Zorro Ranch:
  • Young women were flown to the ranch on Epstein's planes
  • The isolated location made it difficult for victims to escape or seek help
  • Staff were required to sign non-disclosure agreements
One survivor described being taken to the ranch as a teenager and being sexually abused by Epstein. The ranch's remoteness - far from major cities, surrounded by desert - was part of its function as a location where rules didn't apply.

The FBI Search

In August 2019, FBI agents searched Zorro Ranch:
  • Timing: The search occurred after Epstein's death in jail
  • Evidence: Agents removed boxes of materials
  • Questions: Critics wondered if evidence had been removed before the search
The full results of the search remain under seal, but the investigation confirmed that authorities viewed the ranch as a significant location in their case against Epstein's network.
Zorro Ranch was Epstein's fantasy made real - a private kingdom in the desert where he could pursue his ambitions without interference. The property combined scientific pretension, political access, and alleged criminal activity in one isolated location. Today, the ranch remains a monument to how wealth can create spaces beyond normal oversight - and what can happen in those spaces when no one is watching.
